overview.title: What are Proper Nouns?
overview.description: Proper nouns are the specific names of people, places, organizations, days, months, languages, events, and unique things. They always begin with a capital letter, no matter where they appear in a sentence.
key_points: Name unique people, places, or things
Help make meaning precise and unambiguous
Examples: Sarah, London, Monday, India, Facebook
overview.importance: Proper nouns help us talk about specific entities clearly and avoid confusion in conversation.

sections.title: Definition and Identification
sections.content: Proper nouns refer to the names of specific people, places, organizations, holidays, historical events, and brands. They are not general categories, but unique labels. For example, 'city' is common but 'London' is proper.

subsections.subtitle: Proper vs. Common Nouns
subsections.text: Proper nouns are always capitalized and name only one unique person/place/thing, while common nouns are lower case and refer to many possible items.

sections.title: Types of Proper Nouns
sections.content: Proper nouns include personal names, geographic locations, company names, specific holidays/days/months, languages, brands, and titles of works.

sections.title: Capitalization Rules
sections.content: Proper nouns are always capitalized wherever they appear in a sentence. This distinguishes them immediately from common nouns.

subsections.subtitle: Rule Application
subsections.text: Always use a capital letter: 'Paris', 'Apple', 'World War I', 'Saturday'.

grammar_rules.title: Capitalize all proper nouns
grammar_rules.description: Proper nouns must begin with uppercase letters even in mid-sentence.
grammar_rules.tip: Check if naming something unique‚Äîalways capitalize.

grammar_rules.title: No 'a' or 'an' before proper nouns
grammar_rules.description: Do not use indefinite articles before proper nouns.
grammar_rules.tip: Use articles only for common nouns.

grammar_rules.title: Use 'the' with some proper nouns
grammar_rules.description: For certain geographical names and organizations, use 'the' (e.g., The United States, The Taj Mahal).

grammar_rules.title: Do not pluralize most proper nouns
grammar_rules.description: Proper nouns generally refer to single entities and do not have regular plural forms.
grammar_rules.tip: Pluralize only for people with same name, not for unique places/companies.

grammar_rules.title: Titles and works as proper nouns
grammar_rules.description: Titles of books, movies, or songs are always capitalized.
grammar_rules.tip: Capitalize all main words in titles.
